Last year we ran python scripts on a Jetson Nano that used networktables and cscore. Unfortunately, Jetson Nano runs Ubuntu 18.04. I started upgrading these scripts for 2023, but I’m not able to install the needed python modules. I assume this is because WPILib now requires Ubunto 22.04+. Any ideas?

Additional info… last year we used pynetworktables, but it looks like we should now use pyntcore. Here’s the output from installing pyntcore:

robotics@jetson-nano:~$ pip3 install pyntcore
Collecting pyntcore
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/e7/aa/8da69f7ada33294344b4c61ebef8d8fcb7f79262ab0aa947d6a8a1477299/pyntcore-2023.2.1.0.tar.gz
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip-build-yujrlw2d/pyntcore/setup.py", line 3, in <module>
        from robotpy_build.setup import setup
    ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'robotpy_build'

    ----------------------------------------
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip-build-yujrlw2d/pyntcore/

robotics@jetson-nano:~$ pip3 install -U robotpy[cscore]

The Jetson is running Python 3.6, but it could probably be upgraded. 3.8 seems to be the latest “supported” version, but I might be able to go newer.

Here are some more things I tried. I ran pip3 install robotpy_build and it was successful. After that, pip3 install pyntcore got a lot further but it still failed.

Next I tried upgrading to python 3.8.

sudo apt install python3 python3-dev

Now I was successful at installing robotpy_build. However, when I tried to install pyntcore I got errors about wpiutil.

/tmp/pip-build-d4ygt_eo/robotpy-wpiutil/wpiutil/include/wpi/DataLog.h:12:10: fatal error: span: No such file or directory
   #include <span>
            ^~~~~~
  compilation terminated.
  error: command '/usr/bin/aarch64-linux-gnu-gcc' failed with exit code 1

I think I’m be blocked now since I can’t update Ubuntu.

OK, I managed to get gcc 11 installed, but I’m not sure if this is the “right” way. I don’t know if ppa:ubuntu-toolchain-r/test is the right repository to use, but it worked.

I installed it with these commands:

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:ubuntu-toolchain-r/test
sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install gcc-11 g++-11 cpp-11

I set the tools to be the default alternatives with these commands:

sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/gcc gcc /usr/bin/gcc-7 90 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/g++ g++ /usr/bin/g++-7 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/gcov gcov /usr/bin/gcov-7 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/gcc-ar gcc-ar /usr/bin/gcc-ar-7 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/gcc-ranlib gcc-ranlib /usr/bin/gcc-ranlib-7 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/aarch64-linux-gnu-gcc aarch64-linux-gnu-gcc /usr/bin/aarch64-linux-gnu-gcc-7 && \
sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/cpp cpp /usr/bin/cpp-7 90

sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/gcc gcc /usr/bin/gcc-11 110 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/g++ g++ /usr/bin/g++-11 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/gcov gcov /usr/bin/gcov-11 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/gcc-ar gcc-ar /usr/bin/gcc-ar-11 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/gcc-ranlib gcc-ranlib /usr/bin/gcc-ranlib-11 \
                         --slave /usr/bin/aarch64-linux-gnu-gcc aarch64-linux-gnu-gcc /usr/bin/aarch64-linux-gnu-gcc-11 && \
sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/cpp cpp /usr/bin/cpp-11 110

It looks like it’s set up:

robotics@jetson-nano:~$ g++ --version && gcc --version
g++ (Ubuntu 11.1.0-1ubuntu1~18.04.1) 11.1.0
Copyright (C) 2021 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.  There is NO
warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.

gcc (Ubuntu 11.1.0-1ubuntu1~18.04.1) 11.1.0
Copyright (C) 2021 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.  There is NO
warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.

Now I get this error trying to install robotpy_wpiutil.

OSError: /lib/aarch64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0: version `GLIBC_2.30' not found (required by /tmp/pip-build-dre3xhf4/robotpy-wpiutil/build/lib.linux-aarch64-cpython-38/wpiutil/lib/libwpiutil.so)

Which is fair, the WPILib docs do say glibc >= 2.32 is required. I don’t think there is a safe way to upgrade glibc.

Are you able to upgrade your Jetson Nano to Ubuntu 22.04?

If not, you can still use robotpy-cscore from last year. 2023 ntcore is backwards compatible with the NT3 protocol that pynetworktables implements.

We publish pre-built wheels that could work. Install like this:

pip3 install --find-links https://tortall.net/~robotpy/wheels/2023/raspbian/ pyntcore robotpy-cscore

I’ve been away from home all week, so I haven’t had time to update the documentation.

[edit: it’s likely that the prebuilt wheels will require Ubuntu 22.04 since that’s what WPILib requires]

Using last year’s libraries worked. I’ll post this in case someone else finds themself looking for the solution:

# Install older pynetworktables library
python3 -m pip install pynetworktables

# Configure OpenCV path and install 2022 cscore
export CPPFLAGS=-I/usr/include/opencv4
python3 -m pip install robotpy-cscore===2022.0.3

If anyone is struggling to build an old robotpy-cscore, my packages on the OpenSUSE Build Service are still available for Ubuntu 18.04 ARM, as it turns out.

You’ll want the python3-cscore binary package. If downloading manually for offline install, grab python3-networktables too.

Keep in mind that this currently has robotpy-cscore 2021 rather than 2022. If anyone particularly needs a 2022 version then I could upload a new version.
